title: Wednesday, 8th May 2019
bodyHTML:
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Welcome! To Markets Live, FT Alphaville's 11am markets show give or take 20 minutes.

VV75 morning
Soundbuy Morning
Blank canvas good morning everyone
Grouchmonkey Bonjour
Maverick Morning Gents
Kiwi-juice hello
BornCynic Morning - you having a bad day BE?
nightingale20201 morning all
SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all
BE11:20am

Apologies. I let time run away with myself elsewhere. Not for good reason either.

lonrho good morning, anything on Imperial Brands fall.
Kiwi-juice IMPS please. I bought that at £22, sold at £38 and now it is back at £22.
Bluesky21 Good things come to those who wait?
puppyofwallstreet whats good
BE11:21am

Certainly not for story purposes.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

So let's cut the preamble and get right into it I guess.

BE11:22am

Imps? Two requests in early so that's a good place to start.

Bluesky21 @Kiwi-juice - IMPS is now IMB in new parlace, because that way most people will forget what it does :)
Deep Breath everyone... afternoon
Are we there yet You do know busy is the new stupid
BE11:22am

So ........ the problem here's Blu.

GBKrona Jambo
11:23 am
BE11:23am

I just went to the Blu website and it did this .....

BE11:23am

VV75 chatbot?
BE11:24am

Which is a sell signal if ever I saw one.

Bluesky21 Is "Robert" real or a bot?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Anyway, Blu looks to be a flop in the US.

GBKrona Robert the Robot
BE11:24am

Where -- as we've said repeatedly -- the market for vaping's quite complicated.

Bluesky21 Always struck me as odd that Imperial Brands thought they could succeed with blu in the US, when BATS is still losing share and Altria threw in the towel by buying Juul
BE11:25am

Imps were in the right place for demand -- vaping rather than heat-not-burn -- but still seem to have struggled against you know who.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Revenue up 2%, operating profits up 30% but the City 'experts' think it is a sell. Go and figure! My advice: don't listen to nonsense.
rw42 Ugh i hate all AI. Chat robots, idiotic voice recognition on all bloody services you phone, all of it!
Bluesky21 @1st Lt. Fletcher Christian. If you take out FX and adjustments, op profit was flat
11:26 am
BE11:26am

So. First-half US next-gen sales up just £22m to £61m

BE11:26am

And management has a caution of sorts about how much of last year's £300m was actually just pipeline effects and IP royalties that won't repeat.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian More like an opportuniy for creating fear, supporting hedge-fund shorting and hitting another Woodford stock.
rw42 Although i've just thought up the term artificial moronics to more accurately describe it..
Bluesky21 From the IMB presentation: "HY18 AOP excl. other gains £1,584m; HY19 constant currency £1,587m"
BE11:27am

Meaning, to cut to the chase, there's less reason to believe the idea that next-gen will compensate for the 6.9 per cent drop in cig volumes.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Is it in the price though? Maybe.

BE11:28am

Here's Citi.

BE11:28am

We think Imperial’s miss on the top line is more important than the
beat on margins and EPS, as it suggests Imperial is struggling to compete in NGPs in the U.S. Even before these results Imperial had a higher dividend yield (about 8.8% for CY19) than P/E (about 8.1x), implying investors were extremely skeptical about the outlook. We believe that if the company can start to demonstrate better growth, there would be considerable upside in the stock. However the 1H19 results haven’t done that.

Soundbuy ITV - a tad zzzzzzzzzz...........off 6%
Bluesky21 Does the "pending" tag next to my comments mean I have inadvertently done something inappropriate? If so, would appreciate clarification on what that is.
A. M. @Bluesky21: I could see you, and then your comment disappeared..
11:29 am
BE11:29am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:29am

Bottom line: We see no material changes to consensus and expect a muted share price reaction on the back of what was a known soft 1H19 result. Cigarette volumes down 6.9% (cons -5.9%), Blu sales of £148mn (cons £176mn) and 1H 19 Adj tobacco operating profit growth worth £78mn largely offset by higher NGP investment of £65mn.

Grouchmonkey If anyone fancied a run at ITV as rumoured a few months ago, now would be good timing.
BE11:30am

Key positives: 12) Underlying tobacco volume growth closer to industry average of -4.5%, 1H results were impacted by shipment timing. 2) Improved cigarette market share in the US (a first since their acquisition of the US business) although we highlight that a large part of this has come through in the discounter brands segment, 3) 90% of pricing implemented in 1H and IMB expects 2H performance to better reflect the underlying volume momentum and improved pricing. Key negatives: 1) Cigarette market share losses in key Western Europe markets of UK (-40bps), Germany (-50bps), Spain (-40bps) and France (-250bps) 2) Slower than expected momentum in Blu in the US, 3) Cost savings expectation of £60mn vs initial expectations if £80mn as IMB re-phased various initiatives. We continue to believe Imperial would need to make material further investment in NGP to drive revenues and to insulate itself from a rapid shift towards reduced risk products in its top 10 markets (greater than 70% of EBIT).

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And Barclays.

BE11:30am

IMB reported a mixed1H19, in our view.Positives:(a) 1H19EPS was115p, 5% above Barclays and 2% above VUMA consensus(113p). (b) Tobacco margins expanded by 90bps,and 200bps at constant currency on an underlying basis ex one-time gains in 1H18. (c) IMB gained share in the UScig marketfor the first time since the US acquisition in 2015. (d) 1H19 dividend growthwas 10%. (e)IMB reiterated FY19 guidance for FY19 ex-FX revenue growth at or above 1-4%, and EPS growth of 4-8%.Negatives: (a) 1H19 US blu revs were down 45% vs. 2H18 from £112mn to £61mn, in a market that grew 50%(Nielsen reports that blu retail sales grew 9% in 1H19 over 2H18).In our view, IMB built significant inventory in 2H18, 1H19 sales undershot planmassively, leading to an inventory drawdown. (b) 1H19 NGP numbers saw significant growth in Europe and Japan, with revenues increasing from £3mn in 1H18 to £87mn in 1H19. Investors will right ask whether this revenue run rate is sustainable in light of the issues experienced in the US. (c) IMB lost 40bps market share in European tobacco.

BE11:31am

s the 4%+ FY19 revenue growth guidance achievable? Assuming tobacco businessrevenue growth of1% and annualizing 1H19 NGP revenueswouldresult in FY19 revenue growth of 2.5%. IMB expects 2H19 NGP revenues to accelerate as its 1H19 £94mn investment in blu bears fruit in 2H19, and as it launches its heated tobacco product (Pulze).One can argue that 1H19 US NGP revenues are now understating the in-market sales due to inventory drawdown, akin to PM’s experiencein Japan. We think US blu revenues are now relatively clean, based on our analysis of JUUL’s revenues. What to dowith the stock?IMB trades at 8x PE, a multiple ascribed to companies with declining revenues. We build 0% revenue growth for NGP post FY19–IMB has historically not been the best at execution.These results will bring back investor concerns. Stock is unlikely to outperform peersnearterm, barringdivestitures at high valuation. We think managementshould focusits NGP effortsandresources on a few key markets with a big prize,such as the US,rather than spreading itself too thin.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian " implying investors were extremely skeptical about the outlook. " Really? How did you figure that one out?
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Sorry about the run-on words.

undefined
Viking1 Morning everybody
BE11:31am

Honestly, how many f_____g times. The FT comment moderation system's garbage.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Yields were higher on BP and Shell a few years' back and investors then did very well.
11:32 am
BE11:32am

If you get a "pending" tag it's nothing to do with me. I, however, have to go fix it in the back end. Which takes time.

Bluesky21 FT comment moderation system didn't like me accusing Robert at blu of being a "bot". Will keep quiet patiently on my end.
A. M. @BE: we know you're telling the truth, 'cause of the profanity (see also today's further reading)
Bluesky21 @BE - thanks for the fix!
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Blu is a good product.
BE11:33am

I've now done that. Happy now? Good. Right.

undefined
Grouchmonkey @fletcher turned out people weren't ready to give up fossil fuels just yet. Not sure the same is true of smoking.
Petit1 Thank you
11:33 am
BE11:33am

ITV? Sure. it's advertising again.

wayneJ Morning. Read Lucy Kellaway's piece on the Mandarin Oriental today. Was thinking to myself, I would love BE to do such a piece....
Bluesky21 Altria distribution + Juul product + Philip Morris IQOS probably unbeatable. IMB should just give up on NGP in the US ...
Tom Dalgleish Is Lucy back?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian IMB turnover is only 10% US. Come on!
Grouchmonkey @BE I'm still pending, apparently
A. M. @waynej: it is a good read. I like the fact that she discusses Veblen/Giffen goods with her pupils.
BE11:35am

For the seven or eight decades I've been doing this job, people have been writing "ITV's studios investments lessen its reliance on advertising and make it more resilient to cyclical pressures" ...........

Excel Developer @waynej: didn't lucy kellaway quit?
nightingale20201 @excel..Lucy went teaching
BE11:35am

... then results come around, ad loses a point or two and everyone sells.

Bluesky21 @1st Lt. Fletcher Christian: US is 27% of IMB EBIT, though this includes 5% from cigars
wayneJ @Tom - guest appearance; @AM - indeed - I wish I had had such a teacher (I suppose it would have required me to study economics).
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian The world is infactuated by the US. It would be better to marginalise such a FAIL.
11:35 am
BE11:36am

Today, same deal. Headline's okay, ad revenue for H1 looks weak, Brexit gets blamed as per.

BE11:36am

Credit Suisse can summarise.

BE11:36am

1Q19 revenues +2.1% ahead: ITV’s 1Q revenues were £743m, +2.1%
ahead of consensus of £728m (CSe £730m). Within that B&O was in-line
with consensus expectations with total advertising -7% (in-line with guidance)
impacted by macro uncertainty and the absence of Easter. The small beat
came from studios which grew +1% YoY, impacted by a tough comp but
came in +4.1% ahead of consensus.
■ 1H total adv guided to -6%: On outlook the group guided to -6% 1H total
adv implying c-5% for 2Q impacted by a tough World Cup comp in June and
again "economic and political uncertainty". We see this, again, as slightly
disappointing and evidence of the frustrating ongoing headwinds in UK
advertising. Elsewhere, the group reiterates expectations for "good" organic
growth at FY18 in studios and double-digit growth in Online.
■ SoV remains strong, total minutes decline: ITV family SoV was +4% in
1Q, replicating FY16-18 strength and Online viewing +16%. Total viewing
however slipped to -4% in 1Q vs +3% in FY18.
■ Catalysts include progress on BritBox (sole comment today that they're "on
track" for a 2H19 launch) and an improvement in the political/macro
backdrop in the UK. Key risks are macro and execution around Britbox.
■ CS estimates lowered for advertising: With lingering UK macro uncertainty
evidenced by another tough guide in Q2 we lower FY19 total adv estimates
from -1% to -2.5% (vs cons -1.8%), implying broadly flat total adv in 2H19.
This takes CS revenues -1% and due to high op leverage adj EBITA -3.8%.
■ TP unchanged: We flow through our downgrade to our DCF with this offset
by us lowering our FY19 discount period. As such our TP and rating remain
unchanged. Whilst the lingering macro uncertainty is a frustrating weight, we
see ITV's integrated producer broadcaster model as best in class and believe
valuation overly punishes the group. ITV trades on an attractive 9.3% FY20e
FCF yield.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Blue - so 27%, what about the other 73%? And isn't that an advantage seeing as they have the FDA losing its head?
11:37 am
BE11:37am

More importantly, you have the analyst equivalent of the ravens leaving the Tower.

BE11:37am

Ian Whittaker at Liberum is no longer buying ITV.

BE11:37am

It's been 11 years with a buy. Today, not.

Bluesky21 IMB's "Growth" markets are Middle East and Russia
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Our first thought on reading ITV’s Q1’s trading statement was that, while it was disappointing to us because there was not the beat vs guidance we had expected given STV’s recent trading statement, the shares still looked attractive. However, on further reflection, we have downgraded to Hold because we do not see a material improvement in conditions any time soon and we are having to put through another material downgrade to forecasts. There are many things to be positive about ITV, especially on its viewing performance, and the shares are undoubtedly cheap but, with an uncertain political environment and a continuing pattern of downgrades, it is hard to push a Buy case now.

Bluesky21 Other markets are basically a list of countries where the governments really hate cigarettes (France, Australia, UK, etc.)
A. M. @waynej: economics is one of the topics I regret not studying (others are statistics and fluid mechanics).
chad_john Was it Liberium who had the 300p+ target or something on ITV?
BE11:39am

Our target price of 145p (from 190p) is based on c.10x 2019 adjusted PE, which we think is appropriate given the uncertainties. This is a discount to our 180p DCF valuation, which shows there is potential fundamental upside in the shares but we think this is unlikely to be realised given the prevailing headwinds.

No interest in boosting stake, nor selling.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Most analysts seem to be in awe of the executives and don't often ask the pertinent and more challenging questions. So they have to make up more of their own story to then slap it into their DCF model and hey presto - another comic to read!

The interior, designed by Joyce Wang, gives an instant feeling of sterility, drabness and vulgarity. Everything is textured. The doors are made of what appears to be a dark, corrugated melamine. The theme, I’d learnt, is meant to be Hyde Park. Brass statues of deer wander across the furniture. Ducks fly across textured walls. The metal chandeliers are like clumpy branches of a tree.

The hotel restaurants, including Dinner by Heston Blumenthal, Bar Boulud and Breakfast by Mandarin Oriental, are open to non-residents

And the natural progression there is to 'Spoons.

J D Wetherspoon PLC (JDW:LSE): Last: 1,285, down 60 (-4.46%), High: 1,340, Low: 1,264, Volume: 93.63k
wayneJ @Dec69 - one has to wonder about the rapid gunfire style of upgrades of management expectations in some stocks - what is the pressure management is facing to do that? And how can one verify those numbers?
11:52 am

LFL's slowing again.

red @wayneJa mechanic doesnt listen to what the driver tells him but listens to the engine...
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE the quoted rates I find are normally there to make paying guests feel awesome by the discount they achieved.
A. M. 630GBP - get a reasonable++ room for 150GBP and a nice ticket to the ROH
BE11:53am

And because costs are largely fixed or rising, profit's getting crushed.

BE11:53am

Here's Peel Hunt to summarise.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

In H1, PBT fell by 23% despite LFL sales rising by 6.3%. The
deterioration was attributed to higher rising cost pressure, and labour costs in particular. Against a backdrop of minimal price increases (according to CGA’s data, Wetherspoon drinks’ price discount to the sector has increased from 18% to 23% over the last year), EBIT margins fell by 180bps despite the benefit of £56m of freehold reversions reducing the rent roll.

wayneJ Dear ROTR - should we do a whip around to pay for a Premier Inn o/n (think it is £19) for a BE review? (Start small and he will be in the Mandarin in no time).
A. M. There are better ways to engage in conspicuous consumption.
Kiwi-juice any grey on Ontex please ?
BE11:54am

(@Dec69: true, though people -- or more often companies -- do book rack rate.)

BE11:54am

In H2, PBT is forecast to rise by 27%. The recent trend in LFL sales points
to a H2 outcome of c7%, slightly higher than H1’s figure. Although
management has been clear that cost pressure is not abating, they “anticipate
a trading outcome for this financial year in line with our previous
expectations”. That requires a 120bps increase in EBIT margins (110bps for
consensus), against a backdrop of:
• H1 pricing being “up a bit, but by less than inflation over the last 12
months”;
• Applying a random pricing strategy. “It’s very difficult for people to
counteract because even we don’t know what we’re doing!" (regarding
pricing). After all;
• “There’s more of a relationship than people realise between price and
volume.”

11:54 am
BE11:54am

The H1 results were well below our expectations, and given the company’s
sub-6% PBT margin and sensitivity to even small pricing changes, our
confidence in the FY outcome is declining, from already low levels.
 Where there is more certainty is expansion and cash flow. Expansion is at
the bottom of the previous guidance range, with just five pubs/hotels opening
in 2019E, and, after at least £70m of freehold reversions, net debt should rise
by just c£15m this year.
JDW’s asset quality continues to rise, with a freehold ratio that is now above
60%, but this is not converting to higher profitability and margins. That
requires higher pricing, but unless there is any visibility or confidence in
this occurring, we believe it is difficult to have more than a Hold
recommendation with the valuation at 18x P/E and 9.9x EV/EBITDA.

red everytime i think prices are getting excessive here in poland i am brought down to earth with western prices
Dec69 - Skeptic @WayneJ. I find it hilarious companies upgrade when their subcos have leaked letters about serious problems in paying the basic costs I.e. Wages.
Kiwi-juice sh*tty results, thank god for them they do toilet paper.
wayneJ In some companies I have found the personal assistants or sec or corporate travel agent get the airmiles / hotel points.....no incentive to squeeze down prices
BE11:55am

(@wayneJ: I pledge to match any amount raised to avoid spending a night in a Premier Inn.)

BE11:55am

And Canaccord.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

At a strong performance since the start of the calendar year, Wetherspoon's share price has lacked direction since early March and this is unlikely to change unless management displays a renewed determination to turn revenue into profits. Using the current share price, Wetherspoon trades on a PE of 16.7x for FY19E falling to 16.0x for FY20E. It looks expensive on PE metrics but looks more sensible on cash-based metrics (the way forward post IFRS16, in our view). It trades on 9.2x EV/EBITDA for FY19E and 8.8x for FY20E. Our 1250p share price target (was 1300p) remains based on c.9.0x EV/EBITDA and +8.0% FCF yield for FY19E.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Because it's better to have Lou Rawls and not need him than to need Lou Rawls and not have him.

BE12:02pm

I digress. Here's Liberum.

BE12:03pm

1Q’19 LfL sales of -1.5% missed consensus by 100bps. Europe LfL sales fell 6.7% in on lower volumes due to retailer brand contract losses. Americas, Middle East, Africa, Asia LfL sales rose 5.7% on broad-based growth. The Americas performed well including Brazil and the U.S. while the Middle East and Africa also showed growth. Healthcare LfL sales fell 2.1% largely due to a tough comp (1Q’18 6%). Babycare sales fell +3.2% LfL although pants continue to perform well. 1Q adj. EBITDA fell 7.8% yoy to €53m while margin contracted 60bps to 9.7% hurt by adverse FX of €8.5m. Ontex reiterated 2019 guidance for further top-line growth in emerging markets lower revenue in developed markets but the group now expects to stable adjusted EBITDA at constant FX. Ontex launched a new transformation program designed to reignite growth and lift margins.

Kiwi-juice thx on Ontex, if you can on biotech firm Maxcyte - MXCT please
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

And UBS.

BE12:04pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
Ontex's Q1 LfL sales declined -1.5%, a miss versus consensus at -0.5%. Positive pricing and mix in all categories and divisions was more than offset by negative volumes. The miss versus consensus was driven by greater than anticipated volume declines in Europe; see below. Q1 adjusted EBITDA margin was down -190bps (versus Q1 2018 pro forma for IFRS 16) to 9.7% or -40bps at cFX, in line with consensus (9.7%). Analyst conf. call is at 8am UK, followed by an Investor update at 10:30am UK.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
(1) Q1 LfL sales missed consensus in Europe (-6.7% vs cons -3.7%) and in Healthcare (-2.1% vs cons -1.8%) but came in slightly ahead in AMEAA (+5.7% vs cons +5.1%). (2) At the product category level in Q1: Babycare -3.2%, Femcare -6.3% and Adult Inco +1.5% (3) Ontex has introduced a new Transform2Grow initiative, with the aim of driving sustainable profitable growth and value creation; to be discussed at the Investor Update. Ontex will incur €130m of associated costs (€85m one-offs, €45m incremental capex; €45-50m will be realised in 2019. (4) Net debt increased to €940m (3.74x net debt/EBITDA) versus FY18 IFRS 16 pro forma of €908m (3.44x net debt/EBIDTA).
Q: Has Ontex's outlook/guidance changed?
Yes - for 2019 Ontex now expects "stable" adjusted EBITDA at cFX versus an expectation to improve adjusted EBITDA at cFX previously. On LfL sales, Ontex still expects to see “further top-line growth in developing markets, and lower revenue in developed markets”. Prior to today's results consensus expectations for 2019 were: +0.8% LfL sales growth, +10.3% adj. EBITDA margin (-120bps on IFRS16 pro forma, or +10bps on FY18 reported) and adj. EPS of €1.37 (+1% y/y). Ontex has also introduced a 2020-21 outlook, where it expects LfL revenue to outperform its markets by at least +50bps and cFX EBITDA margin improvement of +125-175bps compared to 2018.
Valuation: we think Ontex's discount to EU Staples is justified
Ontex currently trades on 15x 2019E PE, representing a c35% discount to EU Staples ex-tobacco. Our €19 PT is based on a 12.5x 2020E PE multiple.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Both announcements this morning will be a blow to NSF in its ambitions for PFG. NSF now has until 15th May to declare the offer unconditional as to acceptances. While the Schroders rejection means the acceptance condition of 90% can no longer be met, NSF could go with a Scheme (with 75% acceptances) or waive the acceptance condition and declare the offer unconditional as to acceptances. NSF currently has acceptances of 51.3% but we believe this is likely too low a threshold to declare the offer unconditional as to acceptances (as the NSF management team seeks significant change at PFG) and whether or not it will do so depends on the acceptances that come in over the next week (bearing in mind many PFG shareholders will wait until the 11th hour to accept or reject). We also wonder if the Schroders rejection will inspire other residual PFG shareholders to follow suit. Overall, the ball is still in NSF's court, but the recent developments raise the bar in getting the deal done in its current form in our opinion.
